metadata.case_name: Mirza Ali Akbar Kashani v. United Arab Republic & Anr.

facts.text: Contract made between appellant and Respondent No. 2 on March 27, 1958, whereby Respondent No. 2 agreed to buy tea from appellant and give appellant first refusal for additional requirements.
During tenure of contract, respondents wrongfully placed order for tea with third party without giving appellant chance to comply.
Republic of Egypt and Republic of Syria merged to form United Arab Republic (Respondent No. 1) on February 22, 1958, recognized by Government of India.
Respondent No. 2 is a department of Respondent No. 1 and part and parcel thereof.
Suit instituted by appellant on August 10, 1959, without consent of Central Government under s. 86 CPC.
Leave under Clause 12 Letters Patent granted by trial Judge as part of cause of action arose within Calcutta High Court jurisdiction.
Respondents entered appearance on December 3, 1959, and applied on December 17, 1959, to revoke leave, reject plaint, stay proceedings.
Trial Judge held s. 86 not bar, no immunity under International Law, no waiver; dismissed respondents' application.
Calcutta High Court (Letters Patent Appeal) upheld no bar under s. 86, but allowed appeal on immunity under International Law and waiver; rejected plaint.
Appellant obtained certificate and filed appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit is barred under s. 86 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, as it is against a foreign State without consent of Central Government.
Whether respondents enjoy absolute immunity from suit under International Law.

petitioner_arguments.text: S. 86 creates bar only against Ruler of foreign State, not against foreign State itself like United Arab Republic.
Transaction is commercial, not governmental; no immunity under International Law; trend towards restrictive immunity for commercial acts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: International Law (citing Lauterpacht, Dicey, Rahimtolia v. Nizam)

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents submitted to jurisdiction by appearance and filing pleas, waiving objection.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit is in reality against President (Ruler) of United Arab Republic; barred under s. 86 CPC without consent.
Foreign sovereign State enjoys absolute immunity from suit in Indian courts under International Law.
No part of cause of action arose within jurisdiction; leave under Clause 12 invalid; no submission to jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: S. 86(1) applies to Ruler of foreign State as defined in s. 87A(1)(b), including head of Republican States; suit against foreign State must be in name of State under s. 87.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definition of Ruler includes person recognized as head of State regardless of form of government.

court_reasoning.text: Sections 84, 86, 87 read together cover suits by/against foreign States; s. 86 modifies International Law immunity statutorily.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No consent under s. 86 renders suit not maintainable.

court_reasoning.text: No need to consider International Law immunity as s. 86 governs; High Court erred in holding s. 86 inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory provision prevails over common law/International Law.

holdings.text: S. 86(1) CPC bars suit against Ruler of foreign State (including head of Republican State) without Central Government consent; applies to present suit against United Arab Republic.
No consideration of absolute immunity under International Law needed where s. 86 applies.

precedents_cited.relevance: Dissent by Lord Denning supporting restrictive immunity.
Private rights of State distinguished from political/territorial rights under predecessor s. 431 CPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chandulal Khushalji v. Awed Ritz Umar Sultan Nawaz Jung Bahadur
precedents_cited.relevance: S. 86 creates modified privilege based on sovereign immunity principles.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs suits by/against foreign States/Rulers; requires consent for suits against Ruler of foreign State.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held suit barred under s. 86(1) CPC due to lack of Central Government consent; appeal dismissed without considering International Law immunity.

key_quotes.text: "No Ruler of a foreign State may be sued in any Court otherwise competent to try the suit except with the consent of the Central Government certified in writing by a Secretary to that Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct quote of s. 86(1) CPC central to holding.

key_quotes.text: "Ruler, in relation to a foreign State, means the person who is for the time being recognised by the Central Government to be the head of that State."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Definition from s. 87A(1)(b) extending s. 86 to Republican heads of State.

key_quotes.text: "The effect of s. 86(1) appears to be that it makes a statutory provision covering a field which would otherwise be covered by the doctrine of immunity under International Law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains statutory override of International Law.
